div.div: Φιλοκτήτης : Philoctētes, son of Poeas, from Meliboea in Thessaly. A famous archer, he possessed the bow and arrows of Heracles, without which Troy could not be taken. On the way to Troy he was bitten by a serpent in the island of Chryse, near Lemnos, and the Greeks left him behind sick in Lemnos, Il. 2.718, 725, γ 190, Od. 8.219.
From A Homeric Dictionary (Georg Autenrieth, New York, Harper and Brothers, 1891)
